Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Threat Perception on the First Anniversary of the Boston Marathon Bombings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
On April 15, 2013, two bombs exploded near the finish line of the Boston Marathon, killing 3 and injuring more than 250. This tragedy was stressful for many of those living in the Boston metropolitan area, even those not attending the Boston Marathon. Social psychological research can help us understand how experiencing this type of event can affect us; for example, do these experiences influence how we perceive and respond to our social environment? Do we see the world as more threatening after experiencing this type of event? Previous research conducted by the PI and colleagues demonstrate that in the weeks after the Boston Marathon bombing, people had an altered tendency to see threats in ambiguous situations. The current research will use the context of the first anniversary of the Boston Marathon bombing to further examine this question; specifically, the PIs will longitudinally examine how media coverage surrounding the anniversary can change how people with low and high exposure to the initial event perceive potential threats. Participants will include people living or working in Boston at the time of the original event (high exposure group) and people not living in the area at the time of the original event (low exposure group). The study will be conducted at 3 waves: 2 months before the anniversary (Wave 1), within 1 month of the anniversary (Wave 2), and 2 months after (Wave 3) the anniversary. At each wave, participants' exposure to media coverage of the bombing will be assessed, and they will complete a threat perception task. In this task, participants view a person holding an object against a background scene for short intervals. Participants must quickly decide whether the person they see is threatening (e.g., holding a gun) or non-threatening (e.g., holding a soda can or wallet). The researchers hypothesize that those with more initial event exposure and those with more exposure to media coverage of the anniversary of the bombing will show a tendency to misidentify non-threats as threats, and decreased sensitivity to distinguishing threats from non-threats.


This study will be the first to examine the effect of news coverage of real-world mass violence on changes in threat perception over time. This research will have real-world applied impacts by showing how threat perception changes before and after a terrorism event anniversary with heightened media coverage. Alterations in seeing threats, such as "seeing" a person holding a gun when they are holding a wallet, can have serious real-world implications for those working in jobs that require threat perception every day (e.g., police officers or military personnel). This work also could reveal potential detrimental real-world consequences of highly evocative media reporting of the anniversary of a terrorism event, particularly for vulnerable individuals (such as those with higher event exposure). The individual differences approach used here also will help us to identify those at highest risk for altered threat perception in the context of media attention to a prior terrorism event.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

On April 15, 2013, two bombs exploded near the finish line of the Boston Marathon, killing 3 and injuring more than 250 people. This tragedy sent shockwaves through the Boston community, fueled by a hunt for the perpetrators, further bloodshed, and a city-wide lockdown. As evidenced by our own data, there was altered threat perception among Boston community members immediately following these events. We hypothesized that altered threat perception and heightened arousal would be triggered again by extensive media coverage around the first anniversary of the bombings on April 21, 2014, when the Boston Marathon was run again. We used this rare and fleeting opportunity to assess how renewed media attention to this still very salient and much discussed terrorist threat impacted threat perception before and after the first anniversary. We assessed how threat perception for physical objects (guns vs. non-guns) was affected by the diffuse contextual priming of threat caused by heightened media coverage around the first anniversary of the bombings. To study how media coverage affects threat perception over time, the study was performed across 3 waves: two months before (Wave 1), within the month before (Wave 2), and two months after (Wave 3) the first anniversary of the Boston Marathon on April 21, 2014. The team assessed diffuse contextual priming via self-report measures of individual exposure to media coverage of the bombings and other threat-related events and compared threat perception across the three waves in those with low vs. high initial event exposure (i.e., those living in or not living in Boston at the time of the bombings). The team also measured individual differences in initial event exposure (via self-report), and physiological arousal (via negative affective potentiation of acoustic startle to marathon-related images).

Intellectual Merit Outcomes

This research makes a significant scientific contribution to knowledge of how arousal engendered by initial exposure to a terrorism threat and later increases in media coverage impact threat perception bias and sensitivity. It is one of the first studies to examine the effect of real-world mass violence on threat perception using a longitudinal design to specifically track changes in arousal as it fluctuates with rising and falling media attention to the anniversary of a recent terrorist event. Preliminary findings demonstrate that participants reported greater recent media exposure at the wave of data collection immediately preceding the anniversary of the bombings relative to the other two data collection points further from the anniversary. We also find that the sample, as a whole, has a more liberal threat detection bias at the wave of data collection immediately preceding the anniversary compared to the other two data collection points, indicating that participants have a greater tendency to perceive people as threatening near the anniversary of the bombings, even without any in-lab manipulation. Importantly, results also indicate that people's emotional reactions to incidents of mass violence are more indicative of their biased threat perception than exposure to the incident per se. While feeling more affected by the bombings predicted that an individual would have a more liberal threat perception bias, self-reported exposure did not. Moreover, we found no differences in threat perception performance between participants who lived and worked in Boston at the time of the bombings and those who were new to the Boston area.
